data.title: [Next project] Jean-Christophe, by Romain Rolland
data.text:
Bob Reus unread, to Standard Ebooks With seven books produced so far, I think I'm ready to take on a bigger project. I would like to work on the roman-fleuve Jean-Christophe by Nobel Prize winner Romain Rolland. The book was initially published in 10 volumes over a span of three years, but the English translation by Gilbert Cannan is spread over three titles, as are the PG transcriptions. I assume that, as with The Forsyte Saga and In Search of Lost Time, we want them in one production? Looking at the scans and transcription, I don't think that this will give me a lot of trouble, other than the sheer length of the book. The transcriptions seem fine and italics are intact. The only thing that stands out is that the books have two ways of breaking paragraphs: rows of asterisks, and blank lines. I can replace the asterisks with hr-tags, but how would I stylize the blank lines to differentiate them from the other thematic breaks? Jean-Christophe (Vol 1-4) PG: https://www.gutenberg.org/ebooks/7979 IA: https://archive.org/details/jeanchristophe01roll/ Wordcount: ~230k Jean-Christophe in Paris (Vol. 5-7) PG: https://www.gutenberg.org/ebooks/8149 IA: https://archive.org/details/jeanchristophe02roll_0 Wordcount: ~169k Jean-Christophe: Journey's End (Vol. 8-10) PG: https://www.gutenberg.org/ebooks/7967 IA: https://archive.org/details/jeanchristophe03roll/ Wordcount: ~193k Total wordcount: ~592k Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jean-Christophe https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Romain_Rolland Alex Cabal unread, to standar...@googlegroups.com OK, sure. You can cut the section in the preface that mentions the volume divisions unless you want to edit it in some way to make sense for our new format. The footnotes should be updated to point to whatever the actual section in the ebook they should point to. Bob Reus unread, to Standard Ebooks Eight volumes done, two to go. I'm running into a few things I don't know the answer to: 1. In the final few volumes, there are a some illustrations: There are two musical scores in Vol. 8 (links to scans: first, second) that should clearly be recreated in MuseScore Then there is this one, which serves as the header to the prologue of Vol. 10. Also a musical score, but handdrawn and with handwritten lyrics underneath. The handwritten quality seems relevant here, so a case could be made for using a cleaned-up version of the original. The same goes (to a lesser extent) for this score in the middle of Vol. 10. And then there is this full page image right before the start of Vol. 9. 2. There are a couple of instances of the below formatting, which trigger lint errors. Should I change this in any way, or rather add these instances to the lint-ignore file? [...] They were discouraged in advance: they kept on saying:

“There is nothing to be done:”

or

“Let us try not to think of it.”

3. The 6th and 8th volume are both a single, large chapter. Both have an ordinal I for a header in the scans, which could be confusing (there's no chapter II after all). Replacing these with a margin-top: 20vh as described in SEMoS 7.2.10.9 would look better, but is an editorial change. Should I make any changes here, or leave it as is? Thanks! or

“Let us try not to think of it.”

I think you can put all of these into the preceding paragraph. "Or" is not indented so I think it's meant to be part of one unit anyway. > > 2024-06-07_07-39.png > * > > 3. The 6th and 8th volume are both a single, large chapter. Both have an > ordinal *I* for a header in the scans, which could be confusing (there's > no chapter *II* after all). Replacing these with a /margin-top: 20vh/ as > described in SEMoS 7.2.10.9 > would look better, but is an editorial change. Should I make any changes here, or leave it as is? I think you can leave those chapter numbers there. Nearing the end of this long project! Just a couple of illustrations to fix, a long description to write, and some uncertainties to verify or change: Inline quotations were often italicized in these books. I removed all of them but this one, where I'm not sure how to handle it:

“It is not a matter of fashion,” said Arnaud. “He who does not rejoice to hear a sweet accord of instruments, or the sweetness of the natural voice, and is not moved by it, and does not tremble from head to foot with its sweet ravishment, and is not taken completely out of himself, does thereby show himself to have a twisted, vicious, and depraved soul, and of such an one we should beware as of a man ill-born.⁠ ⁠…”

“I know that,” said Christophe. “It is my friend Shakespeare.”

Arnaud is quoting / paraphrasing Shakespeare here, as is shown in Christophe's answer. Removing the italics would make that less clear. Neither emphasis tags nor blockquotes really fit either. Should I ditch the italics or replace them with single quotes? Then, the divisions. As mentioned before, these books were released as 10 volumes in the original French, and published in 3 volumes (with 4, 3, 3 each) in English. To avoid confusion over this, initially I chose to name and semanticate the divisions as 'books':
for book-1.xhtml, for instance. But the longer I work on it, the less certain I am of that choice. I usually refer to each section as a volume, as in "I'm working on a 10-volume book", and to further complicate things, the preface refers to 'parts'. Should I change Books to something else? There are a few sentences in the book that seem grammatically odd to me: "but she still had her ironical manner and her watchful expression, which there was no disarming." "What man is there can fill the life of a woman and satisfy her immense desire" "what man is there would be worthy to be loved;" "That important personage followed the funeral very correctly, and went immediately it was over" "What was it impelled him to follow them?" Is this correct (British) English for the time period? In addition to the above, there's this sentence: "“So,” he asked, “it was Gottfried [who] taught you?”" where I have added "who" in an editorial commit. If the aforementioned sentences are correct, should I revert this one too? There are a couple of full page quotes in the middle of chapters (see chapter 8-1 in the scans here, and chapter 9-2 in the scans here). I tried formatting these similarly to how I did with "Ite missa est" in the production of The Book of Jade (see source here and the css here), but my selectors, shown below, don't seem to carry over to the built epub: #chapter-8-1 blockquote:nth-of-type(13), #chapter-9-2 blockquote:nth-of-type(2) Am I overlooking something? Thanks again for your answers 
